content: The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" recognizes the threat of international terrorism to the United States and the need to address foreign terrorist organizations raising funds for activities targeting the US. It aims to establish liability for aiding and abetting and conspiracy under US law. The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" establishes liability for aiding and abetting and conspiracy under US law, following the legal framework set by the Halberstam v. Welch case. Persons, entities, or countries that knowingly contribute material support to terrorist organizations targeting the US can be held accountable. The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" holds accountable those who knowingly provide material support to terrorist organizations targeting the US, ensuring access to the court system for victims to pursue civil claims. The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" aims to provide victims of terrorist attacks in the US access to the court system to pursue civil claims against those who have supported the perpetrators. It holds accountable individuals, entities, and foreign countries that have knowingly provided material support to terrorist organizations targeting the US. The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" targets organizations or individuals engaging in terrorist activities against the United States. It amends the United States Code to hold foreign states accountable for international terrorism causing physical harm or death in the US. The "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" removes the immunity of foreign states from US courts in cases involving money damages for physical injury, property damage, or death caused by acts of international terrorism or tortious acts committed by the foreign state or its officials in the US. Nationals of the United States can bring claims against foreign states that would not be immune under this act. Under section 2337(2) of title 18, US nationals can sue foreign states under section 2333 if the foreign state is not immune. A foreign state cannot be sued in US courts for negligence under subsection (b). Technical amendments are made to the table of sections in title 28. Responsibility of foreign states for international terrorism against the United States. Section 2333 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include aiding and abetting liability for civil actions related to terrorist acts committed by designated foreign terrorist organizations. The amendment to Section 2333 of title 18, United States Code, allows liability to be asserted against any person who aids, abets, or conspires with individuals committing acts of international terrorism. This amendment does not affect the immunity of foreign states under the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act. The courts of the United States have exclusive jurisdiction over actions involving foreign states. The courts of the United States have exclusive jurisdiction over actions involving foreign states under section 1605B of title 28, United States Code. The Attorney General can intervene to seek a stay of the civil action if engaged in good faith discussions with the foreign state defendant certified by the Secretary of State. A court of the United States may stay a proceeding against a foreign state if the Secretary of State certifies ongoing good faith discussions for resolution. The stay can last up to 180 days, with possible extensions upon recertification by the Secretary of State. SEC. 6. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or any amendment made by this Act is held invalid, the rest of the Act and amendments remain unaffected. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments apply to any civil action. The amendments made by this Act apply to civil actions pending or commenced after the date of enactment and arising from injuries after September 11, 2001.
